Let’s get Specific

Structural Elements & Advanced CSS Selectors

Working with Selectors

So far we have used selectors that target types of HTML elements. But what if we want to style only certain headings or elements, or if we want to apply styling to a whole section of html elements?

We can create selectors that target an attribute value (of the HTML element), such as an id or class value, or target the type of element, such as <h1> or <p>.

Type or Element Selectors

Type selectors target elements by their element type. For example, should we wish to target all division elements, <div>, we would use a type selector of div. The following code shows a type selector for div element as well as the corresponding HTML it selects.

CSS:

div { ... }

HTML:

<div>...</div>
<div>...</div>

CLASS SELECTORS

When we want to apply the same styles to different elements at once, we use class selectors that target elements with the same class attribute.

Class selectors are a little more specific than type selectors, as they select a particular group of elements rather than all elements of one type.

Within CSS, class selectors start with a full-stop ‘.’ (or period as it’s known in America) followed by the class attribute value. Here the class selector will select any element containing the class attribute value of awesome, including the div element and the paragraph element.

CSS:

.awesome { ... }

HTML:

<div class="awesome">...</div>
<p class="awesome">...</p>

ID SELECTORS

ID selectors are even more precise than class selectors, as they target only one single unique element at a time. Just like class selectors use an element’s class attribute value as the selector, ID selectors use an element’s id attribute value as a selector.

Regardless of which type of element they appear on, id attribute values can only be used once per page. If you need to style more than one element, you need to use the class attribute and selector rather than the id.

To select a specific element by its id we use the hash symbol, #, followed by the id attribute value. Here the id selector will only select the element containing the id attribute value of biglogo.

CSS:

#biglogo { ... }

HTML:

<h1 id="biglogo">...</h1>
